questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have a computer that runs Windows 10. The computer contains a folder. The folder contains sensitive data.
You need to log which user reads the contents of the folder and modifies and deletes files in the folder.
Solution: From the properties of the folder, you configure the Auditing settings and from the Audit Policy in the local Group Policy, you configure Audit privilege use.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
No.

The proposed solution will only enable auditing of privileged actions such as changing system time or restoring files and folders. To meet the goal, you need to enable object access auditing on the folder containing sensitive data, and then configure the auditing settings to log the desired events (such as read, modify, and delete) for the appropriate user accounts or groups. Once auditing is enabled, the logs can be collected and analyzed to determine who has accessed or modified the files.

Selected Answer: B
Set 'Audit Object Access' audit policy
This is correct

choices.C: In Azure AD, assign user1@contoso.com the Security administrator role.
choices.A: In Azure AD, assign user1@contoso.com the Cloud device administrator role.
choices.D: On Computer1, create a local user and add the new user to the Remote Desktop Users group.
choices.B: From the local Group Policy, modify the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right.

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant that contains a user named user1@contoso.com.
You have a computer named Computer1 that runs Windows 10.
You join Computer1 to Azure AD. You enable Remote Desktop on Computer1.
User1@contoso.com attempts to connect to Computer1 by using Remote Desktop and receives the following error message: `The logon attempt failed.`
You need to ensure that the user can connect to Computer1 by using Remote Desktop.
What should you do first?

comments.content:
you can !
like this:
cantoso.com\user1@cantoso.com

Starting with Windows 10 version 20H2, you can use Azure AD groups to manage administrator privileges on Azure AD joined devices with the Local Users and Groups MDM policy. This policy allows you to assign individual users or Azure AD groups to the local administrators group on an Azure AD joined device, providing you the granularity to configure distinct administrators for different groups of devices.
Source: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/devices/assign-local-admin

Here's the proof you can add and azure AD user.

net localgroup "Remote Desktop Users" /add "AzureAD\the-UPN-attribute-of-your-user"

Source: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/client-management/connect-to-remote-aadj-pc
Yes you can . I actualy done it today in my job. But computer must be also in domain.
You can't add Azure AD accounts to local group policy

discussion.content: B is correct

comments.content:
Adding to the above, I've had time to test this on a normal domain, I don't have an AzureAD to use. The only time I can reproduce the error explained is if you enter credentials that aren't recognised, this could only be because the Azure User account isn't recognised on the Computer1 (I'm probably wrong on that but it's the answer I came to)

I created two GPOs one to add a Standard User into the RDP group for a domain computer. The other to enable "Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services". The only time I was able to login using RDP was when the first GPO was present, it made no difference if the second GPO was active or not. So, I'm sticking with D. 

AzureAD may work differently with RDP settings, but I don't know, so I can only work with what I've seen.

discussion.content:
I agree that the answer is D. 

In the link suggested by the moderator (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/security-policy-settings/allow-log-on-through-remote-desktop-services) in the Counter Measure section near the bottom it actually states "For domain controllers, assign the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right only to the Administrators group. For other server roles and devices, add the Remote Desktop Users group." Which is the exact explaination of the differences between B and D

B. From the local Group Policy, modify the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right.

Explanation:
By modifying the local Group Policy on Computer1 and adding user1@contoso.com to the "Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services" user right, you grant the user the necessary permission to connect to Computer1 using Remote Desktop. This allows the user to establish a Remote Desktop session to the computer.

Option D, creating a local user account and adding it to the Remote Desktop Users group, is not the most appropriate solution in an Azure AD joined scenario. While it could potentially work, modifying the Group Policy is the recommended method to manage Remote Desktop access permissions on Windows 10 computers joined to Azure AD.

Selected Answer: D
Deez nuts

B cannot be correct you can not add an AzureAD user to a policy. However you can add an AzureAD account to the Remote Desktop Groups, which should be the preffered method see https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/client-management/client-tools/connect-to-remote-aadj-pc#add-users-to-remote-desktop-users-group

This should be the correct answer for D instead of creating an additional account. If I get this question on my exam against my will I'll go for D...

CHATGPT
group.

Explanation:
By default, Azure AD users do not have the necessary permissions to log on to a Windows 10 computer using Remote Desktop. To enable remote desktop access for a user in Azure AD, you must first create a local user account on the Windows 10 computer and add that user to the Remote Desktop Users group.

comments.content: D. On Computer1, create a local user and add the new user to the Remote Desktop Users group.

discussion.content:
I would go with D. I can't assume that the user has been added to the remote desktop group because the question does not state this. Therefore the first thing I would do is to add the user to the RD group. My next step would be to then modify the user right to allow remote desktop login through local group policy.
I tried so hard to find some type of material to back this up but failed greatly. I simply can't assume the user has already been added.. can someone PLEASE give a solid answer. Article included perhaps? This is killing me.

The answer is correct. Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right is assigned to Administrators and Remote Desktop Users group by Default.
"To use Remote Desktop Services to successfully log on to a remote device, the user or group must be a member of the Remote Desktop Users or Administrators group and be granted the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services right." (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/security-policy-settings/allow-log-on-through-remote-desktop-services).
If you open gpedit.msc and go to Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> User Rights Assignment, you can add user or group directly in that policy. In this case you would add cantoso.com/user1@cantoso.com (domain/username)

Selected Answer: B
B is correct, it ok to add an Azure AD account to Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right from local group policy as I tested.

Added a user to "Allow log..." and in the RDP allowed users it does not show up.
Added same user to RD users group and in the RDP allowed users it does show up.
According to this, the answer is D.

comments.content: cantoso.com/user1@cantoso.com

discussion.content: What would be the final answer and justification?

Answer is D : User1 didn't join the computer1 to Azure AD . 'You' did it. Si User1 is not a member of admin Group (rights given if he joined the computer to Azure AD). SO you have to add his Account to Remote Desktop user manually to allow him to use RDP.
Since D is the closest to net localgroup "Remote Desktop Users" /add "AzureAD\the-UPN-attribute-of-your-user", that would be my choice.

None of these answers seem right, the user needs to be a member of the RD users group and it doesnt say if they are or not, adding a local user makes no sense. Modifying the log on through Remote Desktop Services shouldnt be needed either, that could mess things up for ADmins and RD users and I see no need to modify it anyway. Anyone got any more news on how this question is answered?

It's written that "You join Computer1 to Azure AD. You enable Remote Desktop on Computer1" meaning that 1. it's not user1 who join the computer but "you" and 2. that Remote Desktop has been enabled.
For it to work, the RDP user must have rights. You do that by adding him to the Remote Desktop Users group (D). You MUST NOT "modify the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right" since it contains already administrators and the Remote Desktop User group.
You also do not have to create a new user (typo in the answer D) because the user is already created in AzureAD (first sentence). So you only have to add it to the group. Something like : net localgroup "Remote Desktop Users" /add "AzureAD\user1@contoso.com".
It worked for me in a test lab. But I could not find any way to do the same using graphical tools like Computer Manager / groups...
So the best (not the good) answer is "D" for me.

comments.content: It says RD has been enabled. It says nothing about which users are on the allowed list. By default, only Admins and RD Users group can do this. So, since we do not know what group User1 is in (sorta implies User1 did not join the computer to AAD, this user would need to be added) so they would need to be added so I think it is B.

discussion.content: B is correct as you can simply modify the Local group policy to add the user and allow RDP on the machine for the user.
B is the answer.

Although D (creating a local user account) would also work, I am choosing B as my answer. If you create a local user account then the user would always have to RDP to that PC using that same local user account every time. It will work, they will just have to log in with a .\ in front of the username indicating that they are logging on with a local account.

Whereas in B (adding the domain user in GP -> Allow Log on through Remote Desktop Services) The user can RDP to the computer using their own Domain account.

comments.content: Agreed. I've been thinking about this one for a little while. I just don't see why you would need to create a new local user for RDP access. You should be able to do this with the existing user, and B accomplishes that. The error stated in the question is throwing me off, but I think B is the best answer.

discussion.content:
Voting "B" - follow the policy setting and go to tab for explain - 
"Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services
This security setting determines which users or groups have permission to log on as a Remote Desktop Services client."

I am voting for B.
To use Remote Desktop Services to successfully log on to a remote device, the user or group must be a member of the Remote Desktop Users or Administrators group and be granted the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services right. It is possible for a user to establish a Remote Desktop Services session to a particular server, but not be able to log on to the console of that same server. 

In this instance the user has apparently established a remote desktop services session but cannot log on, which suggests B

comments.content: i have swapped my answer to D. You need to add user1@contoso.com to the Remote Desktop Users but nobody has been able to explain or deny why you need to create a local account on Computer1 as user1@contoso.com is already a user in the tenant.
Otherwise; user1 won't show up when you try too add it to the RD Users local group.

discussion.content:
Yes it's D. From Powershell
net localgroup "Remote Desktop Users" /add "AzureAD\the-UPN-attribute-of-your-user"
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/client-management/connect-to-remote-aadj-pc
Azure Active Directory doesn't have GPO, to manage mobile devices Microsoft offer Intune MDM. For me is D

comments.content:
i am accepting D
Remote desktop services are running on Computer
The local PC and remote PC must be in the same Azure AD tenant this can only be implied from the question.
 user1@contoso.com did not join Computer1 to the domain. If the user who joined the PC to Azure AD is the only one who is going to connect remotely, no additional configuration is needed. Therefore an additional configuration is necessary.

On Computer1
System >Remote Desktop > Enabling desktop has been done 
If the user who joined the PC to Azure AD is the only one who is going to connect remotely, no additional configuration is needed. To allow additional users or groups to connect to the PC, you must allow remote connections for the specified users or groups. Click Select Users -> Add and enter the name of the user or group. 
This is where we apparently add user1@contoso.com
Unable to substantiate why a local account has to be created.

Aside : By default, Azure AD adds the user performing the Azure AD join to the local administrator group on the device.
MB it because we have AAD, user/groups configuration goes from the device to cloud.

discussion.content:
While answer D seems correct, it seems a typo. Ideally creating a local user can't grant access to user in Azure AD. It should say add user1@contoso.com to "Remote Desktop Users" local group on that computer. Following command can be used to add the user to the local group
 net localgroup "Remote Desktop Users" /add "AzureAD\the-UPN-attribute-of-your-user"

comments.content: it says "You enable Remote Desktop on Computer1."

discussion.content: If RDP wasn't enabled, you'd get a "Can't Connect" message. Since you're getting an auth message, RDP is enabled but the user isn't authorised. Therefore D
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/client-management/connect-to-remote-aadj-pc

comments.content: No, it doesn't. You can add all the people you want to Remote Desktop Users. But until you enable remote connections, no one is connecting.
confirms the answer as D

discussion.content: Answer could be D since it's not specified that the user is part of the Remote Users Group.

questions.question_text:
You deploy 100 computers that run Windows 10. Each computer has a cellular connection and a Wi-Fi connection.
You need to prevent the computers from using the cellular connection unless a user manually connects to the cellular network.
What should you do?

choices.B: Run the netsh wlan set hostednetwork mode=disallow command
choices.C: Clear the Let Windows manage this connection check box for the cellular connection
choices.D: Select the Let Windows manage this connection check box for the Wi-Fi connection
choices.A: Set the Use cellular instead of Wi-Fi setting for the cellular connection to Never

comments.content:
Let Windows manage this connection
Determines if your Windows 10 device will automatically connect to the cellular data network when it’s available. Clear the check box if you want to manually connect each time you want to use your cellular data connection. Select it if you want Windows to manage the connection for you. When selected, you’ll connect to cellular data automatically when you’re not connected to another kind of network

discussion.content: C is correct

Selected Answer: C
I vote C too

comments.content: Hahaha, Thanks for the smile on my face.

discussion.content: "You smash the computer with a hammer... does it meet the goal?"
answer is A : if yourPc connect automatically to Wifi,then if type d the command, he will not be able to connect :it's the goal of the question . Why so much discussion ?

Selected Answer: B
It will do the job but also delete the connection password, which will give difficulties when you want to reconnect manually. Therefor B is right.

CHATGPT:
A. Yes, running the command "netsh wlan delete profile name="Wireless1"" will delete the stored profile for the Wi-Fi network named "Wireless1" on Computer1, preventing it from automatically connecting to that network. Therefore, this solution meets the goal of preventing Computer1 from automatically connecting to Wireless1.

Selected Answer: B
Prevent automatically connection is needed, not prevent any connection anymore.

netsh wlan delete profile name="PROFILE NAME"
Qual a dúvida?
Faço o teste rápido e simples, resposta correta.

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A. Tested it and I was not able to auto connect.

Execute o comando para verifiar os perfis disponíveis 
netsh wlan show all

Depois exclua a wlan desejada:
netsh wlan delete profile name="Wireless1"

Resposta: A - Correta!

"...from automatically connecting to Wireless1."
by deleting the wireless profile via netsh this would technically prevent you from automatically connecting to that network

Selected Answer: A
I thank the answer is A

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct
I tasted it.

comments.content: Did it taste good?
They’re not asking for the best method. The asking if the answer meets the requirements

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I would lean toward answer B as the method mention in the question is prevent to connect wireless after deletion instead of automatically connect. The Microsoft way is to uncheck automatically connect checkbox.
A is correct even if is not the best choice

The question wants: [You need to prevent Computer1 from automatically connecting to Wireless1]

Yes sure, if you delete the connection, the it will become an unknows connection to you and if you try to connect, it will ask you for credentials. But this doesn't solve the issue because if the WiFi is configured with a certificate and your computer does have the certificate, then it might connect automatically.

You simply click on the wireless icon near the time/date bring the wireless available, click the desired wireless and simply disconnect. When you do that you will see a check box to automatically connect, just leave it blank. This way it doesn't automatically connect, and you keep all the configuration so when you need it, simply connect!

Answer is A, C:\WINDOWS\system32>netsh wlan delete profile name="llex"
Profile "llex" is deleted from interface "Wi-Fi". Extreme but the goal is met
Does this meat the goal? Yes, for sure. Regardless of the other options which come to mind, it definitely won't automatically connect.

This is a tough one, deleting it would stop it connecting automatically but certainly a sledge hammer approach. setting connection mode to manual seems a fair better choice but technically deleting it would achieve the goal. I hate how Microsoft puts these questions. I think the automatically implies it still is to be used so it must not be deleted. So answer is No I think.

comments.content: This made me change my mind

discussion.content:
"You need to prevent Computer1 from AUTOMATICALLY connecting to Wireless1."
I guess if you do that, you prevent it to connect to Wireless1. In this scenario we want to prevent it to connect automatically, not prevent it to connect, that's why I would say no...
Answer is B; you need to disable Connect automatically when in Range Option from the WIFI Properties
Agree with the answer

Shouldn't this be considered as the correct answer?
netsh wlan set profileparameter name="Wireless1" connectionmode=manual
The command it provides just deletes the *Wireless1*

comments.content: nobody says that we need to connect Wireless1 manually. So, yes, it's meet the goal
Man, that is too much.
You just made my day. Hahahahahahah
according to this logic, we can simply throw the laptop out of the window when we need to turn off something...

The Question hasn't gone into any further depth. If you apply netsh wlan set profileparameter name="Wireless1" to a current wifi profile will it, the next time you get in range connect. The answer is no; its will require authentication and thus wont automatically connect regardless if the connectionmode is still automatic

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have a laptop named Computer1 that runs Windows 10.
When in range, Computer1 connects automatically to a Wi-Fi network named Wireless1.
You need to prevent Computer1 from automatically connecting to Wireless1.
Solution: From a command prompt, you run netsh wlan delete profile name="Wireless1".
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content: No for sure.

Selected Answer: B
No.
The LLTD protocol enables applications to quickly discover devices at the data-link layer, and it enables a central, graphical view of everything that is connected to the network.

Selected Answer: B
I think the answer is B

Selected Answer: B
Correct answer.
I think it´s good answer

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have a laptop named Computer1 that runs Windows 10.
When in range, Computer1 connects automatically to a Wi-Fi network named Wireless1.
You need to prevent Computer1 from automatically connecting to Wireless1.
Solution: From the Services console, you disable the Link-Layer Topology Discovery Mapper service.
Does this meet the goal?
